unnormalised: Hey everyone! Ever feel lost in the alphabet soup after someone rattles off their qualifications? I know I used to! Figuring out what “Mr. Sharma, B.Com (Hons.), MBA” *actually* means can feel like cracking a code. So, let's decode some common educational titles and achievements you might encounter in India, shall we? Think of it as your handy-dandy cheat sheet for navigating the academic landscape.
normalised: Hey everyone! Ever feel lost in the alphabet soup after someone rattles off their qualifications? I know I used to! Figuring out what “Mr. Sharma, B-Com Hons., M-B-A” *actually* means can feel like cracking a code. So, let's decode some common educational titles and achievements you might encounter in India, shall we? Think of it as your handy-dandy cheat sheet for navigating the academic landscape.

unnormalised: First up, let's tackle the basics. You'll often see "B.A." or "B.Sc." – that’s Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Science, respectively. Pretty straightforward, right? But then you get additions like “(Hons.)”, as in "B.A. (Hons.) Economics". That "(Hons.)" indicates that Mr. Khan specialized in Economics and did a deeper dive into the subject. It basically means he dedicated himself intensely to understanding it. These degrees are typically 3 yrs long.
normalised: First up, let's tackle the basics. You'll often see "B-A" or "B-S-c" – that’s Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Science, respectively. Pretty straightforward, right? But then you get additions like "Hons.", as in "B-A Hons. Economics". That "Hons." indicates that Mr. Khan specialized in Economics and did a deeper dive into the subject. It basically means he dedicated himself intensely to understanding it. These degrees are typically three years long.

unnormalised: Moving on, we have the Masters level. "M.A." and "M.Sc." are Master of Arts and Master of Science, following the same pattern as the Bachelor's degrees. Then there's the ubiquitous "MBA" – Master of Business Administration. Pretty much every other person I meet in Mumbai seems to have one! It’s a postgraduate degree focused on business management and administration. It can be a 1 yr or 2 yr course. My cousin, Ms. Verma, did her MBA from IIM Ahmedabad.
normalised: Moving on, we have the Masters level. "M-A" and "M-S-c" are Master of Arts and Master of Science, following the same pattern as the Bachelor's degrees. Then there's the ubiquitous "M-B-A" – Master of Business Administration. Pretty much every other person I meet in Mumbai seems to have one! It’s a postgraduate degree focused on business management and administration. It can be a one year or two year course. My cousin, Ms. Verma, did her M-B-A from I-I-M Ahmedabad.

unnormalised: Now, let's talk about engineering and technology. "B.Tech" and "M.Tech" stand for Bachelor of Technology and Master of Technology. Often, these degrees are followed by the specific engineering discipline, like "B.Tech (Computer Science)" or "M.Tech (Electrical Engineering)". Don't forget "BE" and "ME" too – Bachelor of Engineering and Master of Engineering – they’re essentially the same thing! You’ll hear folks say “he’s a BE, passed out in ’18 from a tier 3 college.”
normalised: Now, let's talk about engineering and technology. "B-Tech" and "M-Tech" stand for Bachelor of Technology and Master of Technology. Often, these degrees are followed by the specific engineering discipline, like "B-Tech Computer Science" or "M-Tech Electrical Engineering". Don't forget "B-E" and "M-E" too – Bachelor of Engineering and Master of Engineering – they’re essentially the same thing! You’ll hear folks say “he’s a B-E, passed out in eighteen from a tier three college.”

unnormalised: For the doctors in the house (not medical doctors yet, though!), we have "Ph.D." – Doctor of Philosophy. It's the highest academic degree awarded after years of research and a super intense dissertation. Dr. Banerjee spent 6 yrs getting his Ph.D from JNU. He specialized in ancient Indian history. Kudos to him! I can't even imagine dedicating that much time to something.

unnormalised: And let’s not forget the medical field! “MBBS” is the Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery – the basic medical degree. After that, you might see "MD" or "MS" – Doctor of Medicine and Master of Surgery, respectively. These are postgraduate degrees specializing in different medical fields. Think Dr. Reddy, MD (Cardiology). He is a renowned cardiologist in Hyderabad.
normalised: And let’s not forget the medical field! “M-B-B-S” is the Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery – the basic medical degree. Think Doctor Reddy, M-D Cardiology. He is a renowned cardiologist in Hyderabad.

unnormalised: You might also see professional certifications listed, like "CA" (Chartered Accountant) or "CFA" (Chartered Financial Analyst). These signify specialized knowledge and skills in finance and accounting. My friend, Mr. Gupta, passed his CA exams in ’22 on his first attempt! It was a huge deal.
